title: Morality is relative to the norms of one's culture. Is it true that to determine whether an action is right or wrong, it will depend on the moral norms of the society in which it is practiced? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. This is a common misunderstanding of moral and cultural relativism. If the moral rightness or wrongness of an action was determined by the norms of the society in which it was practiced, this would lead to all sorts of absurd conclusions and would contradict how morality actually functions in the world. For example, the violent persecution of Jews was a norm in Nazi Germany. Does that make it right? No, of course not. We don’t judge its rightness relative to the norms of Nazi Germany - we judge it relative to our own moral norms. If morality is relative to culture then there is no determining ‘whether an action is right or wrong’ in an objective, absolute sense - only relative to some particular set of values and principles. And the rightness or wrongness of an action may be (simultaneously) determined quite differently by different cultures and ideologies. There is no ‘true answer’, or at least none that we have any objective means to determine.

“Morality is relative to the norms of one's culture. Is it true that to determine whether an action is right or wrong, it will depend on the moral norms of the society in which it is practiced?” Understandable error in your premise: the idea that morality is entirely driven by “cultural norms” is only ONE of the common viewpoints, and from my studies and observations, it’s at MOST only partly true. Having studied a LOT of history, psychology, sociology and even more direct observation of humans and non-humans, I have recognized that beneath EVERYTHING that living creatures do, is physiology. That does NOT mean that everything is directly controlled by DNA, it just means that if you do feel good or bad about events, there is a biological component. Now. Societies ARE collections of individual entities. What we refer to as “cultural norms,” do NOT spring up out of nowhere, as the “morality is entirely cultural” necessarily assumes. “Cultural norms” are the result of the not altogether calm and understanding interaction of all the INDIVIDUALS in the society, trying to survive EACH OTHER’S morality. So where does INDIVIDUAL morality come from? Is that really all due to your parents and local culture? Nope. Obviously not, or no individual would EVER pop up inside an established “culture” and take a different moral path. We would especially never see two children from the same family, behaving differently from each other. Because your premise was (understandably) wrong, you’ve gone on to make another common mistake: deducing that right and wrong, as concepts and as real things (if they are real) are therefore entirely culturally determined. If that were true, no culture would ever change what they think of as right and wrong, but they do, so that is also obviously false. Big fundamental: what does “right” and “wrong” really mean? Most people don’t even notice that in their own minds, they have “smudged” the meaning of right and wrong, trying to mach together the vague sense that right and wrong are independent truths, not subject to opinion or “culture,” and the opposite idea that they are entirely imaginary concepts, with no independent existence. Think about it: if “right” and “wrong” really ARE entirely determined by societal context, then that means that there IS no such thing as actual “right” or “wrong.” There’s just “approved” and “disliked.” And only on a local level, at that. And if you go down THAT logical path, what do you then DO when you find that the culture you are living amongst, thinks that some activity or other is acceptable, while you find it to be disturbing and destructive? Do you sit back, and allow yourself and your loved ones to be abused by the society, because “that’s the norm?” And on a detailed level, if the entire culture DOES officially accept something, but almost everyone who is subject to whatever it is, doesn’t like it, then what? Are all the people who are being abused, to be declared mentally disabled, because they think something that their culture says is right, is actually wrong? “Relative morality,” the idea that morality is culturally or environmentally determined, doesn’t lead to any resolution of anything. It doesn’t give useful answers to questions like yours. But morality independent of a living creature, doesn’t seem to exist either. At least not in much more than a vague, occasionally partly shared way. MOST people don’t care for having thing that they managed to have by their own work, stolen from them. But most people also like very much, getting something for “free.” We have some very complicated economic and legal structures built around trying to figure out when it’s okay to steal things, and when it isn’t. And it’s constantly shifting. So IS there a straightforward answer? In my sixty five year study, I would say no. The only thing left to try, is to accept that morality isn’t actually a thing, in and of itself. It’s more of a dynamic result, something that we can see after the fact, but that doesn’t exist unless there are people actively wrestling with it. And since giving up on it entirely is ALSO an arbitrary MORAL choice, we can’t just dust off our hands and walk away. Sorry I can’t give you more than that.
